summary: The appellant Ranjeet Singh @ Dara appeals against the final Judgment and order of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh, Bench at Indore, in Criminal Appeal No: 469/2000 wherein the order of conviction of the appellant for the offences punishable under 302 IPC, passed by the Special Judge (S.C & S.T Prevention of Atrocities) and Additional Sessions Judge, Indore has been confirmed. On 20 September, 2000 at about 8.00 p.m., the accused Ranjeet Singh, son of Machi Singh, resident of Heeranagar, Madhya Pradesh, came out of his house armed with a sword and stabbed his father to death. The learned counsel for the appellant submitted that the delay in sending the copy of the FIR has prejudiced the appellant as the prosecution case is based only on circumstantial evidence, in matters where the prosecution case is based only or primarily on circumstantial evidence, in matters like Hanumant Govind Nargundkar Vs. Laying down the principles in such cases, this court in the case of Hanumant Govind Nargundkar Vs State of M.P.

summary: The appellants have challenged the legality and validity of the order dated 12.10.2007 passed by the High Court of Judicature at Bombay whereby the High Court dismissed all the three Civil Applications preferred by the appellants herein seeking recall of an earlier order dated 13.06.2006 passed by the High Court which was based on the consent terms duly signed by all the parties. In the case of Budhiya Vesta Patel and Ors vs Nirmala Jayprakash Tiwari & Ors, the trial Court, Mumbai, passed a judgment and order in favour of Budhiya Vesta Patel and against Nirmala Jayprakash Tiwari & Ors. It was the stand of the appellants that the consent decree passed by the High Court in favour of respondent no. 7 and 8 and consequently filing the same in the High Court without obtaining the consent of the appellants amounted to a breach of the scope of the authority conferred on him by the appellants and thus the consent decree passed by the High Court was a nullity.

summary: The Punjab and Haryana High Court has upheld the conviction of Amit Kumar and Anrinder Kumar for the murder of Anita Rani, wife of Amit Kumar, in a so-called "honour killing". The case was registered under Section 302 read with 34 IPC against Amit Kumar, Brij Bhushan, Kailash Rani and Neelam Rani at the Police Station, Moga on the complaint of Anita Rani (Ex.P8), who died on 1st July, 1997. The trial court as also the High Court has meticulously examined and re-examined the entire evidence to conclude that the two appellants are guilty of murdering Anita Rani by setting her on fire as she and her parents had failed to meet the wholly unlawful demands of dowry. summary: Punjab State Electricity Board & Anr vs Ashwani Kumar on 8 July, 2010 Reliance Power challenged a decision of the Punjab State Electricity Board to disconnect its electricity supply to two separate premises on the ground that they were not the same premises. summary: The Supreme Court of India has disposed of two appeals relating to vesting of private forests in Kerala. The appellant, Malayalam Plantations Ltd, had filed an appeal before the Forest Tribunal, Kozhikode, challenging the decision of the Forest Department to exempt them from the provisions of the Kerala Forest Act, 1971. In our view, Section 2(f)(1)(iB) of the Private Forests (Conservation and Management) Act, 1988 should not be construed to exclude lands on which firewood trees are necessary to be grown for a reasonable quantity of fuel to the employees of the estates as well as to the smoke-houses and factories in the estates.

summary: The Supreme Court has ruled that a re-test for recruitment to Group-D posts for those candidates who had obtained minimum qualifying marks in the first written examination against large scale irregularities should be held. A chronology of key events: The High Court held that the decision of the Railway Board to conduct a re-test was illegal, arbitrary and unreasonable and directed the Board to finalise the selection on the basis of the first written test and to issue appointment orders to all the candidates except the 62 candidates against whom there were allegations of impersonation.

summary: Appeal by Rangappa against acquittal in a criminal case under the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881. In this case, the accused had issued a cheque in the name of the complainant for encashment of money which had been spent on the construction of the complainant's house, bearing the signature of the appellant-accused, on a memo which said 'I have written a cheque for Rs. 45,000 in cash as a hand loan to the accused, whereas during the cross-examination it appeared that the complainant had spent this amount during the construction of the accused's house from time to time and that the complainant had realised the extent of the liability after auditing the costs on completion of the house. The High Court has held that once a cheque relates to the account of the accused and he accepts and admits the signatures on the said cheque, then initial presumption as contemplated under Section 139 of the Negotiable Instruments Act has to be raised by the Court in favour of the complainant.

summary: Three appeals by special leave from the High Court of Andhra Pradesh against the orders of the Wakf Tribunal in the case of Ramesh Gobindram (Dead) Through Lrs vs Sugra Humayun Mirza Wakf on 1 September, 2010 have been dismissed and the orders of the Tribunal affirmed. The Wakf Act, 1995 provides for the establishment of Wakf Boards and their powers of superintendence and control over the management of individual wakfs. The respondent-Wakf Board has moved the Supreme Court claiming that the Tribunals set up under the Wakf Act do not have the power to grant reliefs in suits filed before them.

summary: Appeal by U.P. Land Development Corporation & Anr against the order of the Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court which directed them to pay salary to the respondents in the pay-scale prescribed for the post of Assistant Engineer. The appellants were employed as Assistant Engineers by the U.P. Land Development Corporation and Anr in the year 1992 on a contract basis. "It is trite that in the case of the two petitioners, the post of Assistant Engineer (Civil) in the Corporation was abolished on 22.2.1993, as per the U.P. Land Development Corporation & Anr vs Mohd. Ganesh, learned senior counsel appearing for the appellants took us through the documents produced by his clients to show that at the time of engagement of the respondents, sanctioned posts of Assistant Engineer (Civil) were not available in the services of the Corporation and argued that the High Court committed serious error in directing the appellants to pay salary to the respondents in the regular pay scale of the post of Assistant Engineer ignoring that they were engaged for a fixed period on a consolidated salary.

summary: Appeal against the impugned judgment of the Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court dated 02.5.2003. The Wakf Act, 1995 has provided for the setting up of a Wakf Tribunal to decide all disputes, questions or other matters relating to a Wakf or Wakf property. The Supreme Court of India has set aside the Calcutta High Court's decision that the Wakf Tribunal has jurisdiction over eviction proceedings under the Wakf Act.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) on an appeal by Congress leader Sajjan Kumar against his acquittal in a 1984 anti-Sikh Riot case. The appellant has moved the Supreme Court challenging the order of the Delhi High Court dated 20 September, 2010 quashing the charge-sheet filed by the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) against him in connection with the 1984 anti-Sikh riots in Delhi. Section 227 of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cr.P.C.) reads as follows: "Whoever commits an offence which is not exclusively triable by the Court of Session, he or she may, by order, frame a charge against the accused and, by order, transfer the case for trial to the Chief Judicial Magistrate or any other Judicial Magistrate of the first class and direct the accused to appear before the Chief Judicial Magistrate or any other Judicial Magistrate of the first class."

summary: The Supreme Court of India has granted leave to a trade union to appeal against a High Court ruling which had held that Typist-cum-Computer Clerks who had been appointed in the Mumbai Port Trust prior to 1.11.1996 had to work for six and half hours a day, whereas Typist-cum-Computer Clerks who had been appointed after 1.11.1996 had to work for seven and half hours (excluding lunch break). Here are the key points of this case: In a landmark case, the Supreme Court had held that "in one establishment there can be employees having separate duty hours."

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a person with a disability can be appointed as an instructor in a social service institute without any recommendation from the Bihar Public Service Commission (B.P.S.C). On 17th June, 2007, the Patna High Court passed an order directing the Bihar Public Service Commission (B.P.S.C.) to issue an appointment letter in favour of the Respondent, Mithilesh Kumar, for the post of Assistant Instructors (Electronics). Learned counsel submitted that the Respondent's claim for appointment could not have been neutralized simply on the basis of a request subsequently made by the Assistant Director, Social Welfare, to the B.P.S.C.

summary: An extremely unusual order passed by the Jharkhand High Court has fallen for consideration in this appeal. summary: The Supreme Court of India has upheld the conviction and sentence passed by the Trial Court in Sessions Trial No. 4 of 2001 (State of West Bengal) under Sections 302 and 307 of the Indian Penal Code (hereinafter called as the IPC). The appellant, Bipin Kumar Mondal, PW-2, has been convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of Ajit Mondal, PW-1, in Raninagar area of Kolkata on 26 July, 2002. The appellant's son, Sujit Mondal, who had deposed that his father had killed his mother, Usha Rani and brother, Ajit Mondal, has been found to be an independent witness.

summary: The following is a verbatim transcript of the judgement delivered by Altamas Kabir on 28 July, 2010 in the case of P.J.Agro Tech Limited & Ors vs Water Base Limited. On 23rd January, 2003, the Directors of the Appellant No.1 Company were not served with summons by the Court of the High Court, Chennai, in Complaint Case No.1 of 2003 based on the complaint which had been filed by the Respondent No.1. This is an appeal against the order of the High Court of Kanoon, dated 28 July, 2010, in which it was held that a complaint under Section 138 of the 1881 Act would be maintainable against a person who was not the drawer of the cheque from an account maintained by him, which ultimately came to be dishonoured on presentation.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that an appeal under Section 34 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act is not an appeal before the High Court, but rather an application before the District Court. The appellants have challenged the order of the High Court which held that an application for setting aside an arbitral award may not be made after three months from the date of receipt of the award. The application under Section 34 of the Limitation Act was filed in time, by excluding the time spent before the wrong forum.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has set aside a lower court's order directing a Mumbai-based brokerage firm to sell its shares to a foreign fund. The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (ITAT) has ruled that a dividend stripping transaction is not a business transaction and hence the loss claimed by the assessee inter alia on the ground was an artificial loss created by a pre-designed set of transactions. Before us, it was submitted that in any event "loss" is a commercial concept under the Act, if such a "tax loss" is created or suffered without any corresponding financial / commercial loss as the money has in fact been recouped in some other form.

summary: The High Court of Madhya Pradesh has dismissed the appeal of Gopal Swaroop Vs. The High Court in conclusion held that the Will propounded by the defendant-appellant before the Trial Court had been executed in as much as the solitary witness DW-2 Vilas Tikhe did not prove that Shri Lal had signed the Will in the presence of Manoj Kumar and that Manoj Kumar had also singed the Will as a witness. The Bench of the Supreme Court of India has, in the present case, reversed the finding of the Trial Court and the Single Judge of the High Court that the execution of the Will was not proved in terms of Section 68 of the Evidence Act read with Section 63 of the Indian Succession Act.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a tenant can be evicted from a house if the landlord has taken a loan from the tenant. The finding of fact recorded by the court below, that the suit property is not required by the landlord as he is doing his business at another premises for last 35 years, is a question of fact. The suit property is not required by the landlord as he is doing his business at another premises for last 35 years; his son is in employment in Dubai. The Supreme Court of India has held that a question of law or a substantial question of law cannot be entertained by the High Court on this ground.

summary: The Supreme Court has ruled that a preliminary notification issued under Section 6 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 (for short, the Act') cannot now be published. The Hon'ble Supreme Court has quashed the acquisition of land by the Tamil Nadu Housing Board for rehabilitation of roofless persons under the Tamil Nadu Housing Board Act, 1997. Two writ petitions were filed in the High Court of Tamil Nadu challenging the orders of the learned Single Judge in Writ Appeal Nos.796 and 1135 of 1999.

summary: The Supreme Court has taken up the case of Balathandayutham & Anr vs Ezhilarasan on 16 April, 2010 for hearing. The High Court of Tamil Nadu has held that the First Appellate Court was wrong in holding that the subsequent two Wills being Ex.B-19 and Ex.B-20 were not proved in view of non-compliance with the mandatory requirement under Sections 68 and 69 of the Indian Evidence Act. The appellants have challenged the High Court's decision that the Wills of the appellants, Ex.B-19 & Ex.B-20, should be treated as the last Will of the testator.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that the last sale or purchase occasioning the export of goods was granted exemption from the State levy. In Sterling Foods (supra) and Vijayalaxmi Cashew Company (supra), the Court examined the question whether the purchase of raw cashew nuts made by the assessees from the Cashew Corporation of India (for short 'CCI') are in the course of import and, therefore, immune from liability to tax under Indian General Sales Tax Act, 1963. On 14 September, 2010, the High Court of Karnataka allowed the Revision Petition of Azad Coach Builders Pvt.

summary: Two appeals have been heard by the Supreme Court of India on the question of whether the offer price of one hundred and sixty rupees per share made by the appellant M/s Daiichi Sankyo Company Ltd., in its public announcement dated January 19, 2009 for the shares of Zenotech Laboratories Ltd., was fair and lawful. On November 22, 2007 Zenotech announced that it had entered into a Share Purchase and Share Subscription Agreement with Daiichi Sankyo Company for the sale of its shares and control in Zenotech to Ranbaxy. On 20 October 2008, Daiichi Sankyo announced that it had entered into an agreement with Ranbaxy to acquire a 26% stake in Zenotech Pharmaceuticals Ltd.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up an appeal by a tenant who was evicted from a flat in Mumbai. It was held that the defendants had encroached and occupied the sherry portion of the suit property, which was admittedly not let out to the deceased defendant. The Appellate Court set aside the finding of the trial Court on this ground only but confirmed the finding on other grounds of eviction.

summary: This case has been listed for hearing by the Supreme Court on 20 August, 2010. The Supreme Court has held that an Electricity Board can not demand payment of electricity dues from an auction purchaser, who was a third party in the contract between the Electricity Board and the previous occupant. In Isha Marbles (supra), the Supreme Court had held that the recovery of dues from a transferee of an undertaking cannot be unlawful.

summary: The Gujarat High Court has held that an assessee is not liable to pay a penalty under the Income Tax Act. The Learned ASG invited our attention to the provision of Section 271(1)(c) of the Income Tax Act which provides that no deduction could be allowed in respect of the expenditure incurred by the assessee in relation to income which does not form part of the total income under this Act. Section 271(1)(c) of the Income Tax Act imposes a penalty on an assessee who furnishes inaccurate particulars of his income.

summary: The Nagaland State Government Employees Welfare Association & Ors. By Nagaland Retirement from Public Employment (Amendment) Act, 2007 (for short, Ist Amendment Act, 2007), the age of the government employees in the State was enhanced from 57 years to 60 years with effect from November 15, 2007 The High Performance Committee ( HPC) of the Nagaland Legislative Council (NLC) in its meeting held on 23 July, 2009 discussed the issue of length of service of government employees in the State and recommended that the Department of Personnel and Administrative Reforms ( DOP & AR) should be nodal agency to streamline date base of government employees, and put in place a Common Data Base System by coordinating with the concerned departments.

summary: A retired judge of the Karnataka High Court has moved the Supreme Court challenging his discharge from service. The Supreme Court has ruled that a probationer can be discharged from his services if he is found unsuitable to hold the post and there is no violation of the provisions of the Karnataka Civil Services (Classifications, Control and Appeal) Rules, 1957 (for short the 1957 Rules') The Karnataka Government has issued a notification discharging Kazia Mohammed Muzzammil, Ist Additional City Civil and Sessions Judge, Bangalore City from service with immediate effect as he is unsuitable to hold the post of District Judge.

summary: Two appeals have been filed in the Supreme Court by two senior employees of the Corporation of India Limited (hereinafter referred to as "FCIL"), against the Calcutta High Court's decision not to quash a private complaint filed by a company against them for offences under Sections 420, 406 andB of the Indian Penal Code. The appellants had filed a writ petition before the Calcutta High Court against the closure of all the units of FCIL except the Sindhri and JMO units. Learned counsel appearing for the appellants argued that the High Court was correct in declining to exercise its jurisdiction under Section 482 of the Explosives Act.

summary: The Supreme Court has held that a person belonging to a scheduled caste in relation to a particular State would be entitled or not, to the benefits or concessions allowed to scheduled caste candidate in the matter of employment, in any other State. The Supreme Court has held that the words "for the purposes of this Constitution" must mean that a Scheduled Caste or a Scheduled Tribe must have right under Articles 14, 19(1)(d), 19(1)(e) and 19(1)(f) of the Constitution. The Supreme Court of India has held that the power of the President is limited to specifying the castes or tribes which shall, for the purposes of the Constitution, be deemed to be Scheduled Castes or Scheduled Tribes in relation to a State or a Union Territory.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notices to the Union of India and Madras Bar Association on appeals challenging the constitutional validity of Chapters 1B and 1C of the Companies Act, 1956. The Eradi Committee was set up by the Government of India to examine the causes of delay in dissolution of companies and to recommend measures to address them. The High Court held that the provisions of the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) and National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) of the Act which were defective were unconstitutional.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued notice to the Madhya Pradesh government on appeals filed by 17 convicts sentenced to life imprisonment for murdering two Muslim men in 1994. The appellants were convicted by the Sessions Court of Madhya Pradesh under Sections 304 Part-II, 323 and 147 IPC for causing injuries to Ashfaq and Shabir. The appellants and the co-accused have been convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment by the High Court of Punjab and Haryana.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has upheld the death sentence of rapist and murderer Aftab Ahmad Anasari. The appellant and Mumtaz were arrested in connection with the rape and murder of Yasmeen Ahmad, daughter of Nayeem Ahmad, resident of village Bajpur, Nainital. Three circumstances were proved by the prosecution, namely, (1) both the appellants were seen by PW3, Naseem Ahmad, at about 4.30 a.m. on February 8, 1998 fleeing from near the place where the dead body of the deceased was found; (2) blood stained frock and underwear of the deceased and blood stained bed sheet were recovered pursuant to voluntary disclosure statement made by the appellant; and (3) extra judicial confession was made by the appellant before PW-5, Anand Swaroop.

summary: The Punjab and Haryana High Court has ruled that the sale of a plot of land in Chandigarh by a woman, who later took her own life, had to be completed by 20.12.1978 and the balance sale price had to be paid at the time of registration of the sale deed. The plaintiff prayed for specific performance of the agreement of sale dated 20.12.1978 or in the alternative, if he was found not entitled to specific performance. In this case, the plaintiff Hartar Singh Sangha filed a suit against the defendant Balraj Singh Sangha, her husband and attorney holder, alleging that the defendant had failed to execute the sale deed in pursuance of a decree for specific performance.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a person who was certified 70% permanent disablement after a motor accident can seek compensation under the Motor Vehicles Act. The Motor Vehicles Accident Claims Tribunal, Ranchi, awarded compensation to Arvind Kumar Mishra, who sustained serious injuries in a road accident and lost his future expectancy in life. In Susamma Thomas, the Court of Appeal for the High Court of India had held that "the operative multiplier of an appropriate multiplicand should be 16 as maximum".

summary: The Allahabad High Court has dismissed an appeal of a head constable who was dismissed from service for leaving his post after having tea and medicine. summary: The Calcutta High Court has allowed the appeal of the Steel Authority of India Ltd.& Ors against the judgment and order of the learned Single Judge which had rejected the claim of the respondent for parity in pay. The Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court has ruled that "unequal pay cannot be treated equals" and "any relief sought by the respondent in this case could not be granted". summary: Appeal by G. Vallikumari against order 10.4.2002 passed by the Division Bench of Delhi High Court which declared Section 12 of the Delhi School Education Act, 1973 (for short, the Act') ultra vires the provisions of the Constitution and in so far applicability of the exclusion clause contained therein is restricted to unaided minority institutions. The appellant was a teacher in an aided minority school in Delhi who was removed from service by the management without permission of the Director of the school. The Division Bench of the Supreme Court of India, in the case of Y. Theclamma vs Andhra Education Society & Ors, held: "It is incorrect to contend that sub section (2) of Section 8 does not suffer from unbridled power."

summary: Appeal by special leave is directed against judgment dated January 25, 2006 by the Division Bench of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana at Chandigarh in LPA No.694 of 1995 by which the appellants have been directed to count previous service rendered by respondent No.1, Narata Singh, in the Departments of Punjab State as work charged employee for the purpose of determining qualifying service for pension payable to him as an employee of the Punjab State Electricity Board. summary: An interesting question of law which arises for determination in these Civil Appeals filed by Non-banking Financial Companies ("NBFCs" for short) is: "Whether the Department is entitled to treat the "Provision for NPA", which in terms of RBI Directions 1998 is debited to the P&L Account, as "income" under 2(24) of the Income Tax Act, 1961 ("IT Act" for short), while computing the profits and gains of the business under Sections 28 to 43D of the IT Act?" The Supreme Court has dismissed a plea of a non-banking finance company (NBFC) challenging a decision of the Commissioner of Income-Tax (CCIT) to disallow the provision for bad and doubtful debt on the ground that it was not allowable under Section 36(1)(vii) of the Income-Tax Act. The Department of Income Tax has submitted that the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has deviated from the accounting principles by insisting that the provision for NPA shall not be netted against the assets and should be shown separately on the liability side of the balance sheet so as to inform its user about the quantum and quality of NPA, in a more transparent manner.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has issued the following directions: In this case, we are dealing with the applicability of the Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act (MCOCA) to the activities of the banned Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT). The appellants have challenged the constitutional validity of Section 2(1)(e) of the Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act (MCOCA) so far it relates to promoting insurgency' on following two grounds:- (a) the Maharashtra State legislature did not have legislative competence to enact such a provision; and (b) the part of Section 2(1)(e) of the MCOCA, so far as it covers case of insurgency', is repugnant and has become void by enactment of the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Amendment Act, 2004, amending the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has taken up the appeal of G.V.Siddaramesh against his conviction and sentence of imprisonment for life for offences punishable under the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 and the Indian Penal Code, 1860. A Fast Track Court in Devangere, Karnataka has acquitted a man and his father in a dowry harassment case after finding that there was no demand for dowry and there was acceptance of dowry. The appellant has been convicted and sentenced to undergo R.I for 5 years and a fine of Rs. 2,50,000/- and in default, to undergo R.I for two years for the offence punishable under Section 3 of the Dowry Prohibition Act; to undergo S.I for two years and to pay a fine of Rs. 10,000/-, in default, to undergo S.I for one month for an offence punishable under Section 498-A of the Indian Penal Code; to undergo imprisonment for life for an offence punishable under Section 304-B of IPC.

summary: Citations: Supreme Court of India The Supreme Court of India has ruled that an employee can challenge the date of birth recorded in his service book in the Civil Court. The Punjab and Haryana High Court has ruled that the date of birth of government employees can only be corrected within two years of joining service, and that the suit filed by the plaintiff-respondent cannot be barred by limitation and the decision of the administrative authorities allowing or rejecting the requests for alteration in date of birth is open to judicial scrutiny when challenged before a court of competent jurisdiction.

summary: All references are to the Supreme Court judgments and orders of the Division Bench of the High Court of Punjab & Civil Writ Petition No. The appellant filed a suit against the respondent No.4 before the Assistant Collector, Faridabad, under Section 77(3) of the Punjab Tenancy Act, 1953. The appellant's counsel submitted that the High Court had erred in finding that the application for eviction of the respondent No.4 for non-payment of rent was not maintainable as it was an application for recovery of arrears of rent for the years 1978-1980, 1980-1981, 1981-1982 amounting to Rs.63/- and Section 14-A(ii) of the 1953 Act read with Rule 22 of the 1956 Rules made it clear that a notice in Form N' had to be served on the tenant to deposit the rent and it was only on failure on the part of the tenant to deposit the rent that the tenant is liable to be evicted by the Assistant Collector.

summary: The Supreme Court has set aside the acquittal of a man convicted of murdering his wife by giving her Cyanide. The appellant was convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment by the trial court for the murder of Sweety (PW.10), a resident of Kozhikode, who died of Cyanide poisoning on 31.05.2000. The appellate court has the power to set aside a judgment of acquittal in a case where two views are possible, though the view of the appellate court may be more, the probable one.

summary: Appeal by Asoke Basak, former Chairman of the Maharashtra State Electricity Board The High Court of Maharashtra had erred in not exercising its jurisdiction under Section 482 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) when it quashed a complaint of criminal breach of trust by the Maharashtra State Electricity Board (MSEB) against the then Chief Minister Prithviraj Chavan. Learned counsel for the appellant submitted that in a case under Section 409 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), where the accused is not the complainant, the court is not required to pass a reasoned order, as pleaded by learned counsel for the appellant.

analysis: The High Court of Maharashtra had erred in not exercising its jurisdiction under Section 482 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) when it quashed a complaint of criminal breach of trust by the Maharashtra State Electricity Board (MSEB) against the then Chief Minister Prithviraj Chavan. summary: Appeal by the State of Karnataka & Ors against the Karnataka High Court's decision to regularize the services of three Typist, Literate Assistant and Watchman who were employed on daily wage basis for more than 15 years without the protection of any court or tribunal. In Umadevi, the Supreme Court ruled that an employee should not be made permanent unless he had been appointed in terms of the relevant rules or in adherence to Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution. Para 53 of Umadevi provides: "Employees who have worked for more than ten years without the protection of any interim order of any court or tribunal, in vacant posts, possessing the requisite qualification, are entitled to be considered for regularization."
